<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">This balance represents the amount of the <I>Discover</I> settlement to be refunded to the Company by Morgan Stanley under a separate agreement. The Company recorded a
corresponding receivable in prepaid and other current assets on the Company&#146;s consolidated balance sheets at June&nbsp;30, 2009. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B><I>Covered Litigation </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Visa Inc., Visa U.S.A. and Visa International are parties to certain legal proceedings discussed below that
are subject to the Retrospective Responsibility Plan, which the Company refers to as the covered litigation. For a description of the Retrospective Responsibility Plan, see <I>Note 2&#151;Retrospective Responsibility Plan</I>. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>The Discover Litigation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Company made its scheduled payments in each
of the first three fiscal quarters of 2009 to Discover pursuant to the terms of the settlement agreement. Visa has also received three of four refund payments from Morgan Stanley. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>The American Express Litigation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">American Express met the performance criteria set forth in the settlement agreement for
each quarter thus far, including the third fiscal quarter of 2009, and Visa made each of the corresponding settlement payments. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>The Attridge Litigation
</I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On January&nbsp;5, 2009, this case was reassigned to Judge Feinstein. A hearing took place on May&nbsp;15, 2009 on Defendants&#146; Motion for
Summary Judgment or Summary Adjudication. On July&nbsp;1, 2009, the court denied the summary judgment motion, but ordered the parties to submit affidavits as to whether further discovery should be conducted prior to the court rendering judgment on
the Motion for Summary Adjudication. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>The Interchange Litigation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><I>Multidistrict Litigation Proceedings </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Pursuant to the court&#146;s previous order, putative class plaintiffs filed their Second
Consolidated Amended Class Action Complaint on January&nbsp;29, 2009, which also added Visa Inc. as a defendant. In addition, putative class plaintiffs filed a Second Supplemental Class Action Complaint (the &#147;Supplemental Complaint&#148;)
against Visa Inc. and several financial institutions challenging Visa&#146;s reorganization and IPO under Section&nbsp;1 of the Sherman Act and Section&nbsp;7 of the Clayton Act. In the Supplemental Complaint, putative class plaintiffs seek
unspecified monetary damages and declaratory and injunctive relief, including an order that the IPO be unwound. On March&nbsp;31, 2009, Visa, jointly with other defendants, moved to dismiss the Supplemental Complaint and the Second Consolidated
Amended Class Action Complaint. Briefing on these motions to dismiss was completed on July&nbsp;2, 2009. A hearing on the motions to dismiss has been set for August&nbsp;18, 2009. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On January&nbsp;29, 2009, putative class plaintiffs served on defendants a reply in support of their motion seeking to certify a class of merchant&#146;s, and on
June&nbsp;25, 2009, defendants served a sur-reply in opposition to the motion. A hearing on the motion for class certification has been set for August&nbsp;20, 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><I>BKS Litigation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On April&nbsp;1, 2009, plaintiffs BKS Inc., BKS of LA, Inc. and Keithco Petroleum Inc. filed a complaint against Visa
Inc., Visa U.S.A. and other defendants in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi, which asserts claims similar to those made in the cases transferred to the Multidistrict Litigation Proceedings.&nbsp;The complaint
states that it is made by the named plaintiffs, as well as all other similarly situated businesses.&nbsp;It seeks unspecified treble and punitive damages, as well as damages not to exceed $100 million for each defendant who has acted in violation of
Section&nbsp;1 of the Sherman Act, damages not to exceed $10 million for each defendant who has acted in violation of Section&nbsp;2 of the Sherman Act, damages not to exceed $10,000 for each defendant who has acted in violation of Miss. Code Ann.
sec. 75-21-1, and injunctive, declaratory, and other relief.&nbsp;On April&nbsp;9, 2009, Visa filed a Notice of Potential Tag-Along Action with the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation requesting that this case be transferred to the
Multidistrict Litigation Proceedings for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings. On April&nbsp;27, 2009, the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation entered an order conditionally transferring this case to the Multidistrict Litigation
Proceedings.&nbsp;On May&nbsp;11, 2009, plaintiffs filed a notice of opposition to the conditional transfer order, which they withdrew on May&nbsp;26, 2009. Thereafter, this case was transferred to the Multidistrict Litigation Proceedings.<B> </B>
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Gulfside Casino Partnership Litigation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On June&nbsp;22,
2009, plaintiff Gulfside Casino Partnership filed a complaint against Visa Inc., Visa U.S.A. and other defendants in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi, which asserts claims similar to those made in the cases
transferred to the Multidistrict Litigation Proceedings.&nbsp;It seeks unspecified treble and punitive damages, as well as damages not to exceed $100 million for each defendant who has acted in violation of Section&nbsp;1 of the Sherman Act, damages
not to exceed $10 million for each defendant who has acted in violation of Section&nbsp;2 of the Sherman Act, damages not to exceed $10,000 for each defendant who has acted in violation of Miss. Code Ann. sec. 75-21-1, and injunctive, declaratory,
and other relief.&nbsp;On June&nbsp;25, 2009, Visa filed a Notice of </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">27 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Potential Tag-Along Action with the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation requesting that this case be transferred to the Multidistrict Litigation Proceedings for
coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.&nbsp;Thereafter, this case was transferred to the Multidistrict Litigation Proceedings. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>Other Litigation
</I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Retailers&#146; Litigation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">In the <I>In re Visa
Check/MasterMoney Antitrust Litigation</I>, on March&nbsp;6, 2009, plaintiffs filed a motion to seek a potential securitization of the future MasterCard settlement payments, in which plaintiffs indicated that they also intend to pursue a potential
securitization of Visa&#146;s future settlement payments. After a fairness hearing on April&nbsp;24, 2009, the court executed an order granting plaintiffs&#146; motion regarding the potential securitization of the future MasterCard settlement
payments. On July&nbsp;2, 2009, plaintiffs filed a motion seeking approval of an agreement for MasterCard to pre-pay its future settlement payments at a discount instead of proceeding with a securitization of those payments. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Retailers&#146; &#147;Opt-Outs&#148; </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Visa and GMRI
entered into a settlement agreement, pursuant to which the GMRI case was dismissed on November&nbsp;21, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>&#147;Indirect Purchaser&#148;
Actions </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Visa made its final settlement payment in the West Virginia case on May&nbsp;14, 2009. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>New Zealand Interchange Proceedings </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On February&nbsp;23, 2009, the
Commerce Commission filed a Second Amended Statement of Claim which alleges that the setting of default interchange rates by Visa post-IPO still contravenes the Commerce Act. On March&nbsp;20, 2009, the retailers also filed a Second Amended
Statement of Claim with similar allegations. On April&nbsp;27, 2009, Visa filed and served Statements of Defense in response to both the Commerce Commission&#146;s and the retailers&#146; Second Amended Statements of Claim. Visa and counsel for the
Commerce Commission are engaged in settlement discussions which have resulted in a formal proposal by Visa to the Commerce Commission seeking to resolve its action. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><I>Currency Conversion Litigation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On July&nbsp;2, 2009, the court received from the special master a supplemental report regarding the
results of the audit program, their effect on the estimated refund amounts for claimants and recommendations concerning outstanding issues related to claims administration. The court has scheduled a hearing for August&nbsp;6, 2009 concerning the
recommendations set forth in the special master&#146;s report. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Morgan Stanley Dean Witter/Discover Litigation </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Commission filed an additional rejoinder to Visa&#146;s rejoinder dated February&nbsp;27, 2009. On July&nbsp;24, 2009, Visa International and Visa Europe filed
a request for measures of organisation (seeking to have the court pose questions to the Commission) and for decisions on the admissibility of certain evidence. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><I>Parke Litigation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">As of February&nbsp;13, 2009, the parties executed a settlement agreement. The settlement amount is not considered
material to the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">28 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>The ATM Exchange Litigation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2">On April&nbsp;30, 2009, the court issued an Order allowing for certain additional discovery and requiring that all additional discovery be completed by July&nbsp;1, 2009, which was later extended by one week. Both plaintiff and Visa
submitted supplemental expert reports. A final pretrial and summary jury trial charging conference was held on July&nbsp;21, 2009, with the summary jury trial scheduled for August&nbsp;4, 2009. A trial date has been tentatively set for
September&nbsp;8, 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>U.S. Department of Justice Civil Investigative Demands (CIDs) </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On February&nbsp;5, 2009, the Division informed Visa that it closed the investigations that led to the issuance of the September&nbsp;27, 2007 and February&nbsp;26,
2008 CIDs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>State of Ohio Investigative Demand </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On
May&nbsp;15, 2009, the Office of the Attorney General for the State of Ohio issued an Investigative Demand to Visa Inc. seeking information regarding a potential violation of Chapter 1331 of the Ohio Revised Code, Ohio&#146;s antitrust law. The
Investigative Demand seeks copies of documents, data and narrative responses that Visa has produced to the Antitrust Division of the United States Department of Justice (the &#147;Division&#148;) pursuant to the Civil Investigative Demand, or
&#147;CID,&#148; issued by the Division on October&nbsp;10, 2008. The Ohio Attorney General&#146;s Investigative Demand focuses on certain Visa U.S.A. policies relating to merchant acceptance practices, including Visa U.S.A.&#146;s policies
regarding merchant surcharging and merchants&#146; ability to steer customers to other forms of payment. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Hill Country Custom Cycles </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On December&nbsp;22, 2008, the court issued an order dismissing without prejudice the case against Visa. Pursuant to the Court&#146;s January&nbsp;26, 2009 Order,
the plaintiff must file an Amended Complaint no later than May&nbsp;1, 2009 if it chooses to refile. On April&nbsp;28, 2009, the parties reached an agreement in principle to settle the litigation. The settlement amount is not considered material to
the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Venezuela Interchange Proceedings </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Visa was served on November&nbsp;28, 2008 and filed its formal brief on March 26, 2009. The evidentiary phase of the investigation has concluded, but the
competition authority has not yet issued any findings as a result of the investigation. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>European Interchange Proceedings </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On April&nbsp;3, 2009, the European Commission issued a Statement of Objections (&#147;SO&#148;) to Visa Europe, Visa International and Visa Inc. alleging a breach
of European competition law. Visa Inc. and Visa International were served with the Statement of Objections on June&nbsp;1, 2009. The SO alleges a breach of Article 81 of the EC Treaty and Article 53 of the EEA Agreement The SO is directed to Visa
Inc. and Visa International as to Honor All Cards, the no-surcharge rule and what the Commission alleges is the &#147;subsidiary application of the Inter-Regional MIFs to the intra-regional POS transactions with consumer cards.&#148;&nbsp;Pursuant
to existing agreements among the parties, Visa Europe is obligated to indemnify Visa International and Visa in connection with this proceeding, including payment of any fines that may be imposed. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">29 </FONT></P>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Canadian Competition Bureau Proceedings </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On April&nbsp;21, 2009, Visa received an oral notification from the Canadian Competition Bureau that it has initiated a civil inquiry regarding interchange and certain of Visa policies relating to merchant acceptance practices.
Visa has not yet received documentation related to the inquiry. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Kabuki Restaurants </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On January&nbsp;5, 2009, Kabuki Restaurants, Inc. filed a putative class action lawsuit against Visa Inc. in California Superior Court. The plaintiff alleges that
Visa&#146;s practice of imposing fines on acquiring banks for their merchants&#146; failure to abide by certain Visa rules, including fines related to the Cardholder Information Security Program (CISP) and Account Data Compromise Recovery (ADCR)
process, violates California state law, including Business and Professions Code &#167;&#167;17200 <I>et seq</I>. Before Visa filed a responsive pleading to the putative class action complaint, Kabuki voluntarily dismissed the action without
prejudice on February&nbsp;5, 2009. Five days later, Kabuki filed a new lawsuit against Visa, alleging the same causes of action as in the first lawsuit, but only on an individual basis. At this time, Kabuki is not asserting any claims on behalf of
a putative class. On June&nbsp;15, 2009, the parties reached an agreement in principle to settle the litigation. The settlement amount is not considered material to the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements. The settlement was finalized
on July&nbsp;22, 2009 and that same day, plaintiff filed a notice of dismissal with prejudice with court. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Loiseau </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On March&nbsp;17, 2009, Robert Loiseau filed a putative class action against Visa U.S.A. in California Superior Court asserting claims for breach of contract,
unjust enrichment and violations of Business and Professions Code &#167;&#167;17200 <I>et seq</I>. The plaintiff alleges that certain fees associated with and limitations on the use of Visa gift cards are unlawful. On June&nbsp;2, 2009, plaintiff
amended the complaint to add the card issuer as a defendant. Visa U.S.A. filed a demurrer on June&nbsp;29, 2009, seeking to have the complaint against Visa U.S.A. dismissed in its entirety because Visa did not issue the gift cards at issue, Visa did
not set the fees and limitations about which plaintiff complains, and Visa did not collect any of the challenged fees. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>The Reserve Primary Fund </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On May&nbsp;5, 2009, Visa U.S.A. commenced an action in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York against The Reserve Primary Fund (the
&#147;Fund&#148;) and related entities in connection with the Fund&#146;s failure to promptly redeem in full Visa U.S.A.&#146;s investment in a money market mutual fund. On September&nbsp;15, 2008, Visa U.S.A. sought to redeem its entire investment
of over $981 million, plus accrued dividends. The Fund failed to return Visa U.S.A.&#146;s investment within one business day as required by the Fund&#146;s prospectus. Since that time, the Fund announced a liquidation plan and has so far made
interim distributions returning approximately 90% of Visa U.S.A.&#146;s investment. Visa U.S.A. is seeking damages in excess of $98 million, being the amount of its investment currently held by the Fund. Also see <I>Note 3&#151;Fair Value
Measurements </I>and<I> Note 4&#151;Prepaid Expenses and Other Assets</I>. On May&nbsp;5, 2009, the SEC commenced an action in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Fund and has proposed an alternative plan of
liquidation. On July 28, 2009, Visa U.S.A. filed a statement regarding the SEC&#146;s plan. A hearing is scheduled for September 23, 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">30 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>Intellectual Property Litigation </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Vale Canjeable </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On March&nbsp;25, 2009, the First Commercial Judge of Appeals of Caracas issued a new decision on Visa
International&#146;s appeal of the preliminary relief (i)&nbsp;dismissing the appeal; (ii)&nbsp;ratifying the preliminary relief; and (iii)&nbsp;finding Visa and Todoticket liable for legal fees and costs in connection with the appeal (which fees
and costs will not be due until the case is finally decided on the merits). On July 9, 2009, Visa International filed a further appeal as to the March 25 decision on preliminary relief. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Starpay and VIMachine </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">The parties reached an agreement
in principle to settle the dispute in January 2008. On May&nbsp;16, 2008, Visa U.S.A. and Visa International filed a Motion to Enforce the Settlement Agreement against all parties to the agreement, including the inventor.&nbsp;Briefing on that
motion is&nbsp;complete, with the inventor intervening in opposition.&nbsp; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">VIMachine and the inventor subsequently filed a Motion to Compel Further
Mediation on November&nbsp;7, 2008.&nbsp;Visa U.S.A. and Visa International opposed the motion&nbsp;and asked the Court to rule on the pending Motion to Enforce if the parties&#146;&nbsp;efforts to resolve their differences were unsuccessful. On
December&nbsp;17, 2008, Starpay and VIMachine filed a Motion for Leave to File Under Seal a Motion for Stay of This Action in Favor of Arbitration. In an Order of February&nbsp;13, 2009, in which it denied Plaintiffs&#146; pending motions for a
ruling or, in the alternative, a scheduling order, the Court indicated that the parties should expect rulings on the other pending motions in due course. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2">The parties reached a revised settlement agreement (the &#147;Revised Settlement&#148;), which was signed by all parties on June&nbsp;4, 2009 and June&nbsp;5, 2009.&nbsp;Visa made payments pursuant to the Revised Settlement on June&nbsp;8,
2009.&nbsp;The parties planned to file a dismissal of the action with the Court on June&nbsp;9, 2009.&nbsp;However, the Court issued rulings on the parties&#146; previously pending motions on June&nbsp;8, 2009.&nbsp;The Court granted in part and
denied in part the Motion to Enforce, resulting in a set of settlement terms that differ somewhat from those found in the Revised Settlement.&nbsp;Accordingly, on June&nbsp;22, 2009, Visa and the inventor, Talati, filed a Joint Motion for Entry of
Dismissal&nbsp;Vacating Orders of June&nbsp;8, 2009.&nbsp;VIMachine is unopposed to the motion.&nbsp;On July&nbsp;1, 2009, Starpay filed an Opposition to the Joint Motion for Entry of Dismissal Vacating Orders of June&nbsp;8, 2009. The settlement
amount in the Revised Settlement is not considered material to the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Every Penny Counts,
Inc.&#151;Prepaid Cards </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Appellate briefing is complete. Oral argument before the Federal Circuit was held on April&nbsp;1, 2009. On
April&nbsp;30, 2009, the Federal Circuit affirmed the lower court&#146;s judgment in favor of Visa. On May&nbsp;11, 2009, Every Penny Counts filed a petition for panel rehearing of the panel&#146;s April&nbsp;30 decision. The Federal Circuit denied
the petition for rehearing on May&nbsp;26, 2009 and issued its mandate on June&nbsp;2, 2009. Judgment was entered pursuant to that mandate on June&nbsp;10, 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Calabrese Stemer&#151;Transaction Notification Alerts </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On February&nbsp;19, 2009, Calabrese Stemer LLC and Charge
Notification Services Corp, Inc. filed suit against Visa Inc. in the Southern District of Florida for patent infringement. Plaintiffs allege that Visa offers to perform certain transaction notification pilot services that would infringe United
States Patent No.&nbsp;7,357,310 (&#147;Mobile Phone Charge Card Notification and Authorization Method&#148;). On June&nbsp;11, 2009, Plaintiff filed a Notice of Voluntary Dismissal Without Prejudice. On June&nbsp;16, 2009, the Court issued an Order
of Closeout dismissing the Plaintiffs&#146; claims without prejudice. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">31 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>TQP Development, LLC&#151;Data Encryption </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On March&nbsp;25, 2009, TQP Development, LLC filed a lawsuit against Visa Inc., Visa U.S.A., Visa International and a number of other companies, including American
Express, MasterCard and Barclays, in the Eastern District of Texas alleging that methods practiced on the defendants&#146; websites infringe United States Patent No.&nbsp;5,412,730 (&#147;Encrypted Data Transmission System Employing Means for
Randomly Altering the Encryption Keys&#148;). On May&nbsp;22, 2009, Visa answered the complaint and filed a counterclaim for a declaratory judgment that Visa is not infringing the patent and/or that the patent is invalid. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Actus, LLC&#151;Prepaid Cards </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On April&nbsp;9, 2009,
Actus, LLC filed a lawsuit against Visa Inc. and a number of other companies in the Eastern District of Texas alleging that certain Visa prepaid products infringe United States Patent No.&nbsp;7,328,189 (&#147;Method and Apparatus for Conducting
Electronic Commerce Transactions Using Electronic Tokens&#148;) and United States Patent No.&nbsp;7,249,099 (&#147;Method and Apparatus for Conducting Electronic Commerce Transactions Using Electronic Tokens&#148;). On June&nbsp;11, 2009, Visa filed
a motion to dismiss plaintiff&#146;s claims. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Joao Bock Transaction Systems&#151;Transaction Security </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On May&nbsp;11, 2009, Joao Bock Transaction Systems of Texas, LLC filed a lawsuit against Visa Inc. and a number of other companies in the Eastern District of Texas
alleging that certain Visa products and/or services infringe United States Patent No.&nbsp;7,096,003 (&#147;Transaction Security Apparatus&#148;). On June&nbsp;23, 2009, plaintiff filed a first amended complaint. On July&nbsp;10, 2009, Visa filed a
motion to dismiss plaintiff&#146;s claim. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Restricted Spending Solutions, LLC&#151;Prepaid and Commercial Cards </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On May&nbsp;18, 2009, Restricted Spending Solutions, LLC (&#147;RSS&#148;) filed a lawsuit against Visa U.S.A. and a number of other companies in the Central
District of Illinois alleging that certain Visa prepaid and commercial cards infringe United States Patent No.&nbsp;6,044,360 (&#147;Third Party Credit Card&#148;). On June&nbsp;23, 2009, RSS filed a dismissal without prejudice as to all defendants
and, the same day, re-filed its suit in the Northern District of Illinois. At this early stage, it is not possible to make any reasonable evaluation of the claims alleged. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>


<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="toc77497_9"></A>ITEM&nbsp;2.</B></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations </B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>This management&#146;s discussion and analysis provides a review of the results of operations, financial condition and the liquidity and capital resources of Visa Inc. and its subsidiaries (&#147;Visa,&#148; &#147;we,&#148;
&#147;our&#148; and &#147;the Company&#148;) on a historical basis and outlines the factors that have affected recent earnings, as well as those factors that may affect future earnings. The following discussion and analysis should be read in
conjunction with Visa Inc.&#146;s unaudited consolidated financial statements and related notes included elsewhere in this report. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Forward-Looking statements
</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">This management&#146;s discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations contains &#147;forward-looking statements&#148;
within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements can be identified by the terms &#147;anticipate,&#148; &#147;believe,&#148; &#147;continue,&#148; &#147;could,&#148; &#147;estimate,&#148;
&#147;expect,&#148; &#147;intend,&#148; &#147;may,&#148; &#147;plan,&#148; &#147;potential,&#148; &#147;predict,&#148; &#147;project,&#148; &#147;should,&#148; &#147;will,&#148; and similar expressions, which are intended to identify forward-looking
statements. In addition, any underlying assumptions are forward-looking statements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">By their nature, forward-looking statements are not guarantees
of future performance or results and are subject to risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict or quantify. Therefore, actual results could differ materially and adversely from these forward-looking statements as a result of
a variety of factors, including all the risks discussed in Part I, Item&nbsp;1A&#151;&#147;Risk Factors&#148; in our Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2008. You are cautioned not to place undue reliance on such
statements, which are made only at the date of this report. Unless we are required to do so under U.S. federal securities laws or other applicable laws, we do not intend to update or revise any forward-looking statements. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Overview </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Visa operates the world&#146;s largest retail electronic
payments network and manages the world&#146;s most recognized global financial services brand. We provide financial institutions with platforms that encompass consumer credit, debit, prepaid and commercial payments. We facilitate global commerce
through the transfer of value and information among financial institutions, merchants, consumers, businesses and government entities. Each of these constituencies has played a key role in the ongoing worldwide migration from paper-based to
electronic forms of payment, and we believe that this transformation continues to yield significant growth opportunities. We continue to explore additional opportunities to enhance our competitive position by expanding the scope of payment services
to benefit our existing customers and to position Visa to serve more and different constituencies. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Overall Economic Conditions </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Our business is affected by overall economic conditions and consumer spending. We expect that weak economic conditions will continue to moderate consumer and
commercial spending, and our rate of payments volume growth, in the near term. Regulatory measures enacted in the United States during the third fiscal quarter will impact our financial institution customers. The legislation takes effect in February
2010. Should financial institutions constrict credit offerings in response to these measures, this could ultimately impact consumer spending and our payments volumes. However, we believe that the continuing secular shift to electronic payment
products for non-discretionary spending will buffer the impact to our overall payments volume growth. This shift is particularly clear in debit products, where Visa has a strong market position in the United States and significant growth
opportunities internationally. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">33 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Funding of the Litigation Escrow Account </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">During December 2008 and July 2009, we deposited $1.1 billion and $700 million, respectively, into the litigation escrow account (the &#147;Escrow Account&#148;)
previously established under the Retrospective Responsibility Plan (the &#147;Plan&#148;). Under the terms of the Plan, when Visa funds the Escrow Account, its U.S. financial institutions, the sole holders of shares of class B common stock, bear the
cost through a reduction in their as-converted class A common stock. Fundings of the Escrow Account had the effect of repurchasing of 20,800,824 and 11,578,878 class A common stock equivalents, respectively. See <I>Note 2&#151;Retrospective
Responsibility Plan</I> to our unaudited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this report. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Sale of Investment in Companhia
Brasileira de Meois de Pagamento (&#147;VisaNet do Brasil&#148;) </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">In June 2009 Visa International Service Association, a wholly-owned subsidiary
of the Company sold its 10% ownership in VisaNet do Brasil in connection with its initial public offering. As a result of this transaction, we recognized a pre-tax gain of $473 million in investment income, net on our statement of operations. The
amount of the gain net of tax was $237 million. Following their initial public offering, we amended an existing agreement with VisaNet do Brasil which grants a license to use Visa trademarks and technology intellectual property. The license fees to
be earned during fiscal 2010 are expected to offset the loss of dividend income as a result of the sale of our ownership interest. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Expansion of
Our Processing Capabilities </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Expanding our processing capabilities worldwide is a core component of our long-term growth strategy. As part of this
strategy, we created Visa Processing Services Pte. Ltd. (&#147;VPS&#148;), a joint venture with Yalamanchili International Pte. Ltd. (&#147;Yalamanchili&#148;), in which we hold a majority interest. Yalamanchili is a payments processor and software
company with operations in Asia. VPS will allow us to extend our industry-leading processing capabilities in geographies where electronic payments are growing rapidly, providing multi-currency and multi-language debit, credit and prepaid processing
services to financial institutions, processors and payment companies. VPS will also have capabilities to provide ATM, money transfer and private label processing, as well as a range of payments services, including risk and fraud management, mobile
applications, loyalty and cardholder support. Initially, VPS is expected to provide prepaid and debit processing solutions and we believe it will complement Visa&#146;s Debit Processing Service. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Payments Volume and Transaction Counts </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">We believe that
payments volume and processed transactions are key drivers of our business. Payments volume is the basis for service revenues and processed transactions are the basis for data processing revenues. As anticipated, payments volume declined in credit
and commercial products, offset by growth in debit resulting in minimal quarter over quarter payments volume impact. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">34 </FONT></P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">(1)</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Figures may not sum due to rounding. Percentage change calculated based on whole numbers, not rounded numbers. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">(2)</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Includes prepaid volume. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">(3)</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Total volume is the sum of total payments volume and cash volume. Total payments volume is the total monetary value of transactions for goods and services that are purchased.
Cash volume generally consists of cash access transactions, balances access transactions, balance transfers and convenience checks. Total Volume is provided by our financial institution customers, subject to verification by Visa. From time to time,
previously submitted volume information may be updated. Prior year volume information presented in these tables has not been updated, as changes made are not material. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">(4)</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Service revenues in a given quarter are assessed based on payments volume in the prior quarter, excluding PIN-based debit volume. Therefore, service revenues reported with
respect to the three and nine months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009 and June&nbsp;30, 2008 were based on payments volume reported by our financial institution customers for the three and nine months ended March&nbsp;31, 2009 and March&nbsp;31, 2008,
respectively. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Growth in operating revenues earned throughout the rest of the world offset lower revenues in the United
States during the three month period. U.S. revenues reflect volume and support incentives incurred on initiation or early renewal of significant long term customer contracts in the quarter. Operating revenues throughout the rest of the world also
reflect the impact of pricing modifications made on various services since the prior year as a result of innovations in our product line and improvements in our service model. We regularly review our pricing strategy to ensure that it competitively
aligns with the value and growth opportunities provided to our customers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">A significant portion of the revenues we earn outside the U.S. results
from cross-border business and leisure travel which has moderated in the current economic environment. Revenues from processing foreign currency transactions for our customers fluctuate with cross-border travel and our customers&#146; need for
transactions to be converted into their base currency. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Our operating revenues are impacted by fluctuations in foreign currency rates. Operating
revenues are impacted by the overall strengthening or weakening of the U.S. dollar compared to local or regional currencies in which our payments volumes are denominated. The strengthening of the U.S. dollar over the prior year during the three and
nine months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009 resulted in a 5% and 3% decline, respectively, in total operating revenues compared to the prior year comparable periods, which primarily impacted service revenues and international transaction revenues.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">36 </FONT></P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">(1)</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Percentage change calculated based on whole numbers, not rounded numbers. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Service revenues</I> increased during the three month period primarily due to strategic pricing modifications which offset the decline in global payments volume. Growth in
service revenues during the nine month period reflects payments volume growth of 2% and the impact of these strategic pricing modifications. We expect that weak economic conditions will continue to moderate consumer and commercial spending, and our
rate of payments volume growth, in the near term. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Data processing revenues </I>increased due to growth in the number of transactions processed of 8% in both the three and nine month periods combined with strategic pricing
modifications outside of the United States. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>International transaction revenues </I>increased during the three and nine months periods despite negative double digit growth in cross-border payments volume during both
periods. Revenue grew due to competitive pricing modifications made since the prior year comparable periods. We regularly review our pricing strategy to ensure that it competitively aligns with the value and growth opportunities provided to our
customers. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Other revenues </I>increased primarily due to growth in revenues related to the Visa Extras loyalty platform for administrative and rewards fulfillment services performed
in support of the platform. Growth in optional service and product enhancements, such as extended cardholder protection and risk management services, also contributed to the increase. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Volume and support incentives </I>increased in the three and nine month periods primarily due to incentives incurred on initiation or early renewal of significant long
term customer contracts in the current quarter. These incentives were partially offset in the three month period by contractual adjustments reducing incentives previously accrued on superseded contracts. The actual amount of volume and support
incentives will vary based on modifications to performance expectations for these contracts, amendments to existing contracts or new contracts. See <I>Note 10&#151;Commitments and Contingencies</I> to our unaudited consolidated financial statements
included elsewhere in this report. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">37 </FONT></P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">(1)</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Balance represents the net of the current and long term asset and current liability portions of volume and support incentives as presented in the unaudited consolidated
balance sheets of Visa Inc. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">(2)</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Amount represents downward adjustments resulting from management&#146;s refinement of its estimate of projected sales performance as new information becomes available.
Management refined its definition of performance adjustments during the second fiscal quarter to exclude adjustments to estimates made within a quarter and to only include adjustments to estimates made in previous quarters. Of the amount in fiscal
2009, $20 million represents adjustments made related to prior fiscal year estimates and $10 million represents adjustments related to estimates made in the first and second fiscal quarters of the current year. Under our refined definition,
performance adjustments during the first fiscal quarter of 2009 would have been $19&nbsp;million, compared to the previously disclosed amount of $34 million, with an offset to current year provision. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Personnel </I>decreased primarily reflecting the absence of larger severance and other charges incurred in the prior year associated with workforce consolidation and
elimination of overlapping functions, combined with reduced employee incentive-related costs. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Network, EDP and communications</I> increased primarily due to higher fees paid for debit processing services related to processing transactions through non-Visa networks.
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Advertising, marketing and promotion </I>decreased reflecting our global strategy to reduce cost. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Professional and consulting fees </I>decreased primarily due to the absence of consulting and legal fees incurred in the prior year in connection with our global
reorganization, IPO and related insourcing of professional services, and reduced legal fees due to the settlement of outstanding litigation with Discover Financial Services in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2008. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Depreciation and amortization</I> decreased during the nine month period primarily reflecting the absence of amortization expense which was incurred in the second quarter
of prior year on licenses acquired in connection with the <I>PrivaSys</I> litigation settlement in that quarter. During the third fiscal quarter, additional depreciation of $6 million from our new east coast data center was offset by other
technology and facility improvement assets which were fully depreciated since the prior year. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Administrative and other </I>increased during the three month period, primarily due to unrealized foreign exchange losses recorded upon the remeasurement of U.S. dollar
denominated monetary assets, held in our Canadian foreign subsidiary, into its Canadian dollar functional currency. Currency losses recorded in the third quarter reversed currency gains realized during the first half of the fiscal year. The
fluctuation in the nine month period is also offset by the decrease in spending which reflects our overall cost reduction strategy. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Other

2009 compared to the prior year comparable periods. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Investment income, net </I>increased primarily due to a pre-tax gain of $473 million recognized on the sale of our investment in VisaNet do Brasil, partially offset by
lower interest income earned on both our investments in marketable securities and the portion of our IPO proceeds used to redeem the class C (series II) and class C (series III) shares in October 2008. See<I> Note&nbsp;4&#151;Prepaid Expenses and

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Income Taxes </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Our
effective income tax rate is a combination of federal, state and foreign statutory rates and certain required adjustments to taxable income. The effective income tax rates were 44% and 41% for the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009 and 2008,
respectively, and 41% and 34% for the nine months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009 and 2008, respectively. The rate for the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009 was higher than the rate for the same period in the prior year primarily due to the additional
foreign tax attributable to the sale of our investment in VisaNet do Brasil. The increase in the rate for the nine months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009, compared to the rate for the same period in fiscal 2008, was primarily due to the additional foreign
tax on the sale of the investment in VisaNet do Brasil, and a one-time rate reduction in fiscal 2008 from the combined effect of the loss of a California special deduction upon our IPO and the deferred tax remeasurement benefit due to the change in
state tax apportionment. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Beginning October&nbsp;1, 2008, our subsidiary in Singapore operates under a tax incentive agreement, which is effective
through September&nbsp;30, 2014, and may be extended through September&nbsp;30, 2023, if certain additional requirements are satisfied. The tax incentive agreement is conditional upon our meeting certain employment and investment thresholds. We
anticipate the impact to fiscal 2009&#146;s effective tax rate to be less than one percent. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>Cash Flow Data </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">The following table summarizes our cash flows for
the periods presented: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR BGCOLOR="#cceeff">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Effect of exchange rate changes on cash and cash equivalents</FONT></P></TD>

<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>)&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(779</B></FONT></TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>)&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR STYLE="font-size:1px">
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cash provided by operating activities during the nine months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009 consisted of net
income of $1,839 million and adjustments for non-cash items of $1,072 million. Standard non-cash adjustments for volume and support incentive accruals and depreciation and amortization were offset by a $473 million book gain on the sale of our
investment in VisaNet do Brasil for which proceeds were not received until July 2009 (see <I>Liquidity</I> discussion below). Cash from operating activities also reflects the use of cash of $2,144 million to fund significant operational payments
including those related to settlement transactions, litigation settlement payments, volume and support incentives, and our annual compensation benefits. We believe that cash flow generated from operating activities sufficiently meets the demand of
our ongoing operational needs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cash provided by investing activities during the nine months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009 primarily reflects $884 million
of cash distribution received from the Reserve Primary Fund and net cash proceeds of $276 million from the sales and maturities of investment securities, which were reinvested in money market funds. As of June&nbsp;30, 2009, all of our money market
fund balances, except for the Reserve Primary Fund, were covered under the U.S. Treasury Department Temporary Guarantee Program. We also purchased property, equipment and technology of $205 million primarily related to construction of our new data
center. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">40 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cash used in financing activities during the nine months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009 primarily reflects redemption of
our class C (series II) and class C (series III) liability shares for $2.6 billion, funding of $1.1 billion to the litigation escrow account in December 2008 and dividend payments of $240 million, offset by funding of covered litigation payments
totaling $1,481 million from the litigation escrow account. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>Liquidity </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B></B>Our primary sources of liquidity are cash on hand, a fixed income investment portfolio, cash flow from our operations and access to various borrowing arrangements. In July 2009, we also received approximately $1 billion
in proceeds, net of underwriter discounts and fees, as a result of the sale of our 10% ownership interest in VisaNet do Brasil, and we expect to make payment of associated taxes estimated to be approximately half this amount in the fourth fiscal
quarter of 2009. See <B></B><I>Note&nbsp;4&#151;Prepaid Expenses and Other Assets </I><B></B>to our unaudited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this report. <B> </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">There has been no significant change to our primary uses of liquidity since September&nbsp;30, 2008 except as discussed below. Based on our cash flow budgets and
forecasts of our short-term and long-term liquidity needs, management believes that our projected sources of liquidity will be sufficient to meet our projected liquidity needs for more than the next 12 months. Management will continue to assess our
liquidity position and potential sources of supplemental liquidity in view of our operating performance, current economic and capital market conditions, and other relevant circumstances. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Funding of the Litigation Escrow Account. </I>On July&nbsp;16, 2009, we deposited $700 million into the litigation escrow account. The additional funding had
the effect of a repurchase of 11,578,878 class A common stock equivalents. The funding was approved by our board of directors in June 2009. See <I>Note 2&#151;Retrospective Responsibility Plan </I>to our unaudited consolidated financial statements
included elsewhere in this report. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Dividends</I>. On July&nbsp;22, 2009, our board of directors declared a dividend in the aggregate amount of
$0.105 per share of class A common stock (determined in the case of class B and class C common stock on an as-converted basis). We expect to pay approximately $78 million in connection with this dividend on September&nbsp;1, 2009. We intend to
continue paying quarterly dividends in cash, subject to approval by our board of directors. Class B and class C common stock will share ratably on an as-converted basis in such future dividends. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Pension and other postretirement benefits.</I> Our policy with respect to our qualified pension plan is to contribute annually not less than the minimum
required under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (&#147;ERISA&#148;). We typically fund our qualified pension plan in September of each year. Our nonqualified pension and other postretirement benefit plans are funded on a current basis.
Funding of the plans only impacts current period operating cash flow. Funding does not impact current period pension expense but has the positive impact of reducing future period pension expense for the qualified pension plan. Based on year-to-date
plan asset performance and plan activity, we believe we will fund our pension and other postretirement benefit plans by approximately $104 million compared to $190 million in the prior year. Recent market conditions have resulted in an unusually
high degree of volatility associated with certain plan assets. Should deterioration in market conditions continue, our pension asset portfolio could be adversely impacted, and we may be required to make additional contributions. The ultimate impact
on the funded status and the amount of our annual funding of our qualified pension plan will be determined based on market conditions in effect at September&nbsp;30, 2009. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Visa Europe put-call option agreement</I>. We have granted Visa Europe a perpetual put option which, if exercised, will require us to purchase all of the
outstanding shares of capital stock of Visa Europe from its members. Visa Europe may exercise the put option at any time. The purchase price of </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">41 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">the Visa Europe shares under the put option is based upon a formula that, subject to certain adjustments, applies Visa Inc.&#146;s forward price-to-earnings multiple
(the &#147;P/E ratio&#148;) at the time the option is exercised (as defined in the option agreement) to Visa Europe&#146;s projected sustainable adjusted net operating income for the forward 12-month period (&#147;adjusted sustainable income&#148;).
Visa Europe&#146;s adjusted sustainable income is calculated under the terms of the put option agreement and includes potentially material adjustments for cost synergies and other negotiated items. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">At June&nbsp;30, 2009, the fair value of the put option liability was $346 million. While this amount represents the fair value of the put option at June&nbsp;30,
2009, it does not represent the actual purchase price that we may be required to pay if the option is exercised. The purchase price we could be obligated to pay 285 days after exercise will represent a substantial financial obligation, which could
be several billion dollars or more. We may need to obtain third-party financing, either by borrowing funds or undertaking a subsequent equity offering in order to fund this payment. The amount of that potential obligation could vary dramatically
based on, among other things, Visa Europe&#146;s adjusted sustainable income and our P/E ratio, in each case, as determined at the time the put option is exercised. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Given the perpetual nature of the put option and the various economic conditions which could be present at the time of exercise, our ultimate obligation in the event of exercise cannot be reliably estimated. The following table
calculates our total obligation assuming, for illustrative purposes only, a range of P/E ratios for Visa Inc. and assuming that Visa Europe demonstrates $75 million of adjusted sustainable income at the date of exercise. The $75 million of assumed
adjusted sustainable income provided below for illustrative purposes only is based on Visa Europe&#146;s financial results for the year ended September&nbsp;30, 2008.&nbsp;However, this does not represent an estimate of the amount of adjusted
sustainable income Visa Europe would have been able to demonstrate at&nbsp;September 30, 2008&nbsp;or will be able to demonstrate at any point in time in the future. The table also provides the amount of increase or decrease in the payout, assuming
the same range of estimated P/E ratios, for each $25 million of adjusted sustainable income above or below the assumed $75 million demonstrated at the time of exercise. At June&nbsp;30, 2009, our P/E ratio was 18.3 (as defined in the option
agreement) and the P/E differential, the difference between this ratio and the ratio applicable to Visa Europe, was not significantly different than the assumed long term differential of 5.3x we used to value the put option. However these ratios are
for reference purposes only and are not necessarily indicative of the ratio or differential that could be applicable if the put option were to be exercised at any point in the future. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
